content.description: This route starts just left of Skull & Bones and trends diagonally to the left, following a blocky crack system and a tricky overhang where the crux involves getting your feet up to the lip of the roof. Be sure to bring an alpine-length sling to reduce drag on the third bolt below the roof. A committing crux, but with great holds. The rock in this section of the cliff tends to be fragile, so be extra cautious and be sure your belayer wears a helmet.
content.protection: 8 bolts and bolted anchor. Bring an alpine-length sling for the third bolt.
content.location: Just left of Skull & Bones, at the base of a large crack. This route is roughly 300 ft. left of the parking lot area.

content.description:
Note:

This area is no longer available for top roping.  Look Before You Leak can be climbed from bottom up, then this route top roped from below.

A good line with various options for working up the face.  Stay to the right of the cracks on face climbing. The route up the cracks is the 5.7, Look Before You Leak.
content.protection: The anchors are 2' below the ledge top.
content.location: Starts on a ledge to left side of a small gully between Ground Up and Parking Lot areas.

content.description:
This route is named in honor of local climber Liz Mahanna (1966-2022) who faced her cancer diagnosis the same way she approached all the challenges in her life—with true grit. (Grits was also the name of Liz's ultimate Frisbee team, as well as one of her favorite foods.) This is now a fully-equipped sport route (bolted with permission from the first ascent party).

The climb ascends a short face, trends slightly left to avoid an awkward dihedral, transitions into a short chimney, and finishes on an exposed white arête. A surprisingly long and varied route. The rock in this section of the cliff tends to be fragile, so be extra cautious and be sure your belayer wears a helmet.
content.location: A hundred feet or so to the right of Pontius Pilot.

content.description: This is now a fully-equipped sport route (bolted with permission from the first ascent party) with 10 bolts and a 2-bolt anchor. Climb starts below a giant, dead pine tree and follows an obvious corner and crack system straight to the tree. This was originally a well-protected, but slightly chossy trad lead. The middle section of the climb is slightly overhung, and the crux includes an exhilarating step across the gap between two walls. Also take note: the rock in this section of the cliff tends to be fragile, so be extra cautious and be sure your belayer wears a helmet.
content.protection: The route now has 10 bolts and a 2-bolt anchor. It can also be well protected with an assortment of small to large cams and tricams. A couple of long slings will prevent rope drag through the overhanging section.
content.location: Just left of Pontius Pilot, you'll see a broken crack system leading straight up to a giant, dead pine tree. This route is 300 ft or so left of the Parking Lot Area.

content.description:
The route climbs the obvious bolted arete to a deep ledge under the roof. Traverse left then step up on the ledge. Pull the roof (crux) then continue up to a bolted anchor.

The rock at the roof is somewhat soft and sandy (this is Pilot!).
content.location: Just right of Skull and Bones is a clean arete leading to a roof. This route is about 300 ft or so left of the Parking Lot Area.

content.description: Easily protectable crack system on the left of the wall, just right of the arête. Clamber up a short, dirty gully to access the route. Watch for loose and rotten rock. Crux is about half way up in open book feature, but there's a great crack in the middle of the "book." You can easily top-out right near parking lot. There are now bolted anchors at the top, which should be used for lowering or rappelling. The top of the cliff in this area is now fenced off to prevent access from the hiking trail. There is absolutely no access to this climb from the top of the cliff, and no topping out and walking off. Park officials support new route development in this area only as long as the climbing community observes the cliff top closure.
content.protection: A set of cams works great. Protecting the belay is recommended at either top or bottom. No bolts, except for the bolted anchors at the top. Lower or rappel from anchors. Do not top out or walk off.
content.location: Starts on the ledge above the trail in briars. One of the last routes in the Ground Up area (next to parking lot area).
